title: 106_s382
content: The Act may be cited as the "Minuteman Missile National Historic Site Establishment Act of 1999". Congress finds that the Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missile launch control facility and launch facility known as "Delta 1" and "Delta 9" are significant examples of American history during the Cold War. These facilities symbolize the dedication of Air Force missileers stationed in remote locations and provide a unique opportunity to illustrate the history of the Cold War and ICBM development. The National Park System lacks a unit specifically commemorating the Cold War. The Act aims to preserve and interpret the Minuteman II missile defense system, highlighting its historical role in America's strategic commitment to world peace during the Cold War. It also seeks to complement the interpretive programs offered by the South Dakota Air and Space Museum. SEC. 3. MINUTEMAN MISSILE NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is established in South Dakota as a unit of the National Park System, consisting of the Minuteman II ICBM launch control facilities depicted on a specific map. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to make minor adjustments to the boundary of the Minuteman Missile National Historic Site. The site shall be administered in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park Service Act. The Secretary of the Interior can adjust the boundary of the Minuteman Missile National Historic Site. The site will be managed in compliance with the National Park Service Act. The Secretary must coordinate with other agencies and can make cooperative agreements for the site's administration. Land acquisition is allowed, with exceptions. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with public and private entities to carry out the Act. Land within the historic site can be acquired through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from another Federal agency, with exceptions for contaminated land. The Secretary may acquire land in South Dakota only by donation or exchange. A general management plan for the historic site must be prepared within 3 years of funds availability, including evaluation of visitor facility locations. The Secretary must prepare a general management plan for the historic site, including evaluating locations for a visitor facility and administrative site. The site boundary will be modified to include the selected location. Coordination with Badlands National Park is also required in the planning process. The Secretary will modify the historic site boundary to include the selected location for a visitor facility and administrative site. Coordination with Badlands National Park is necessary in the planning process. Authorization of appropriations is granted for carrying out the Act, including transferring Air Force funds for maintaining the historic site. The Legacy Resource Management Program's funds for resource preservation and treaty compliance are unaffected by this Act.
